image.altText: a woman with brown hair and glasses with a pile of textbooks and a laptop in front of her

props.synopsis: The mature age physiotherapy student is battling what's known as "placement poverty".

title.children: These students have to do 1000 hours of unpaid work but the bills don't stop piling up

image.altText: A clinic worker testing a specimen in a lab.

props.synopsis: In its first two years, Canberra's fixed drug checking service has found meth in a counterfeit diet pill and a synthetic opioid thought to be 25 times stronger than fentanyl.

title.children: Meth in diet pills and synthetic opioid 25 times stronger than fentanyl among things found by drug testing service

image.altText: A rope with a flag in front of a section of lawn which has been worn away.

props.synopsis: A student encampment at the Australian National University disbands after 110 days, after the university's announcement it would no longer invest in "controversial weapons manufacturers" in the long term.

title.children: 'Completely untenable': ANU students disband pro-Palestine encampment after 110 days of protest

image.altText: black and white graphic showing old newspaper articles saying slacks banned

props.synopsis: When Dorothy Henderson-Smart based her decision to wear trousers on convenience, little did she know she'd end up making headlines. Years later, her family has uncovered the story of the "girl who shocked Canberra".Â

title.children: 'The girl who shocked Canberra': Dorothy Henderson-Smart and the fashion choice that sparked a national outcry

image.altText: A main in a white coat holds up a small specimen container while looking into the camera.

props.synopsis: Researchers at the Australian National University create a 'Trojan horse' method they believe could help in the fight against malaria and other potentially deadly parasitic diseases.

title.children: Malaria parasites love cholesterol and that could be their downfall

image.altText: Three men stand with their arms around one another, all smiling.

props.synopsis: Victor Croker and Dave Leemhuis struggled to keep their bees alive during winter so they developed a new insulated hive. It's proved so popular among beekeepers that 500 are now being shipped to the United States each week.Â

title.children: These beekeepers created a new type of hive that's so popular they're shipping 500 to the US each week

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

props.synopsis: The federal government has offered political staffers the maximum pay rise allowed by law, along with new travel allowances, leave for cultural activities and extra pay for staff who speak multiple languages.

title.children: Parliamentary staff poised for pay rise with new cultural leave and travel allowances

image.altText: Untitled design (4)

props.synopsis: Sovereign citizens are using tax time to spread misinformation about the Australian Taxation Office, including the claim "tax is voluntary" and the authority is "not a legal entity".

title.children: Sovereign citizens warned off using 'hopelessly flawed' logic during tax time

image.altText: Man working from home in a creative field on his ipad

props.synopsis: New laws come into effect next week that give workers the right to ignore work communications after hours, but they may not be enough to shift Australians' habit of working long hours.Â

title.children: Australians will soon have the right to switch off after hours â but it might not shift our 'excessive' work culture

image.altText: A composite image of two soldiers, soldiers firing a have weapon, and a brain scan

props.synopsis: Doctors suspect mysterious brain injuries in soldiers repeatedly exposed to blasts and explosions could be the cause of memory loss, headaches, fits of rage and an increased suicide risk.Â

title.children: Some soldiers with brain injuries never saw combat. Now scientists think they know why

image.altText: Michael Lynch smiling and wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Mike Lynch is among six people missing after a superyacht carrying 22 people capsized and sank off the coast of Sicily due to bad weather.

title.children: 'British Bill Gates' Mike Lynch among those missing after superyacht sinks in storm off Sicily

image.altText: A reflection of people walking past the ASX indicator board.

props.synopsis: Two weeks ago, fear that global finance was on the eve of destruction caused a wave of panic as traders from New York to Tokyo battled one another in a race to exit financial markets. Now it's but a distant memory.

title.children: What did we learn from this month's stock market crash? Nothing

image.altText: Kamala Harris smiles and waves on stage.

props.synopsis: The Democratic National Convention kicks off in Chicago, with US President Joe Biden set to give Tuesday's keynote speech as thousands of delegates gather to celebrate presidential nominee Kamala Harris. Follow live.

title.children: Kamala Harris appears at Democratic National Convention, Joe Biden and Hillary Clinton to lead speeches

image.altText: Matthew Richardson of Australia displays his silver medal on an Olympic podium

props.synopsis: Australian cycling has been dealt a massive blow, with dual Olympic silver medallist Matthew Richardson to switch nationalities and compete for Great Britain at international events.

title.children: Aussie silver medallist announces switch to Team GB

image.altText: A female mine worker walks past a mine dump truck at a coal mine in central Queensland.

props.synopsis: Workers are being asked to undergo blood tests as part of the recruitment process, particularly in the mining and resources sectors, with no guarantee their health information is secure, a new report has found.

title.children: 'No blood, no job': The companies ruling out job applicants who refuse to take blood tests

props.synopsis: In Australia, there are more than twice as many children as childcare places, according to a world-first study analysing childcare access down to the street level in nine developed countries.

title.children: Australiaâs childcare divide is growing. Here are the suburbs getting left behind

image.altText: Donald Trump wears a blue suit and red tie

props.synopsis: The joint statement from the FBI and other federal agencies was the first formal attribution of the hack to a foreign entity.

title.children: Iran to blame for Donald Trump campaign hack, US intelligence officials say

image.altText: A large truck drives past a sign that reads 'Welcome to Hughenden'

props.synopsis: The family, including three children under 12, have been taken to hospital as a precaution after jumping from the moving caravan.

title.children: Five people jump from moving caravan after it was stolen in north Queensland

image.altText: Adam Bandt in Mural Hall

props.synopsis: The Greens leader has raised concerns about a bill to force the CFMEU into administration, warning there were "no safeguards" to stop a future Coalition government from appointing Tony Abbott to take charge. Follow live.Â

title.children: 'No safeguards': Bandt claims Tony Abbott could be put in charge of CFMEU

image.altText: Warragamba Dam reached capacity on Saturday May 11 and began spilling on Sunday 12 for the second time this year

props.synopsis: Perfluorinated chemicals (PFAS), considered unsafe in drinking water by the US, have been detected at water filtration plants across Sydney.

title.children: What the 'forever chemicals' found in platypuses mean for the people of NSW

image.altText: A boy with scabs on his face

props.synopsis: Sewage seeping through the streets of Gaza is prompting a new infectious threat to desperate Palestinians.

title.children: 'We've never seen anything like this': Doctors baffled by skin infections spreading through Gaza

image.altText: Journalist Masha Gessen standing in front of a blue background.

props.synopsis: Russian-American journalist Masha Gessen has had their visa to enter Australia granted after an earlier delay. They were convicted in Russia of trumped-up charges of spreading false information.

title.children: Journalist and Putin critic Masha Gessen free to enter Australia after visa delay

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: This morning we'll get more detail from the Reserve Bank of Australia's most recent decision on interest rates (which was to hold them steady). Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.Â

title.children: ASX opens higher as RBA minutes detail more about next rates decision

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ANZ-Roy Morgan: inflation expectations at 2.5-year low

image.altText: Iron ore stockpiles line up on a coastline

props.synopsis: China's cooling property market has seen iron ore prices tumble faster than expected this year, and the decline could see $3 billion wiped from the federal budget. How concerned should WA be?

title.children: As the plummeting iron ore price hits hard, there are fears about the 'huge risk' facing Western Australia

image.altText: Sofia

props.synopsis: From country to country,Â keen sky gazers have diligently captured the first supermoon of the year.Â

title.children: Rare 'blue' sturgeon supermoon lights up global landmarks

image.altText: Larry Emdur on the red carpet holding up his gold Logie award

props.synopsis: With a streaming title sweeping the awards to a convoluted voting process, the 2024 Logies shows how Australian TV is struggling to keep up with a rapidly changing industry.

title.children: The Logies proved that the one-time cultural heartbeat of Australia is facing arrest

image.altText: a woman putting a voting ballot paper in a box

props.synopsis: Residents in a slew of New South Wales council areas will not get to vote in the upcoming September local government elections as not enough people have put their hands up to run.

title.children: 'What's the point?': Elections in 14 NSW council areas called off due to lack of candidates

image.altText: A graphic of marketing through email and social media.

props.synopsis: Ads are getting harder to track and regulate online, making it easier for advertisers to sell unregulated and potentially harmful therapeutic goods.

title.children: Young Australians being 'bombarded' by 'manipulative' dark marketing campaigns

image.altText: A fire inside a Brisbane City garbage truck

props.synopsis: There's been a surge in potentially deadly "hot loads" where batteries or flammables spark an explosion inside garbage trucks.

title.children: Garbage fires force trucks to dump flaming loads of rubbish onto suburban streets

image.altText: Woman with blonde hair sits next to man with short brown hair at a cafe with yellow coffee mugs.

props.synopsis: Choosing to walk away was the hardest decision, but for these farming couples, there's a new life beyond the family property.

title.children: 'You only live once': Trading in the family farm for a different life

image.altText: A man smiles behind a clear square tablet that he is holding up in front of his face.

props.synopsis: A single combined pill could ease the "tablet burden" for people who take multiple medications a day, researchers say.Â

title.children: Researchers use 3D printers to combine multiple drugs into one 'polypill' to reduce 'tablet burden'

image.altText: A gas operation owned by Woodside at dusk.

props.synopsis: The Australian Conservation Foundation says its case was "unlikely to succeed", calls for legislative change, and apologises to supporters.

title.children: Woodside's Scarborough gas project to proceed after conservation group drops lawsuit

image.altText: Man stands in front of American flag gesturing with hand as another man walks beside him

props.synopsis: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke after holding a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday which lasted over two hours.

title.children: US says Israel accepts Gaza ceasefire proposal that Hamas rejected over bias accusations

image.altText: A muscular fisher shows the strain as she hauls in a large fish on a line from the back deck of her fishing boat

props.synopsis: Bruce Davey went to the Gulf of Carpentaria in 1974 seeking adventure and seafood. Decades later, he's still there with his wife Juanita and their family â and they wouldn't have it any other way.

title.children: Couple celebrates '90 years' fishing remote Aussie waters in a job they still love today

image.altText: Oprah Winfrey, left, holds hands with Phil Donahuek right, as he blows her a kiss

props.synopsis: The success of his show paved the way for other daytime talk-show hosts, most notably Oprah Winfrey, whose program eventually eclipsed Donahue's in the ratings.

title.children: Phil Donahue, pioneer of the daytime talk show, dies aged 88
